header.title: Election ITV debate LIVE: Boris cheered as he slams Corbyn for ‘sacrificing the union’
header.subtitle: BORIS JOHNSON has clashed with Jeremy Corbyn in which he blasted the Labour leader for “sacrificing the union”.
header.postText: 'The Conservative Party and Labour Party leaders have gone head-to-head on their positions on Brexit and the deal put forward by Boris Johnson. They were both asked by an audience member if the union is worth sacrificing over Brexit. Jeremy Corbyn said: I hope the union won’ t be broken up in this way but the deal the Prime Minister has put to parliament is about creating a border between the Republic and Northern Ireland.', 'Clearly there are issues all around the deal he has proposed. ', ' This deal is damaging to the country, damaging to the rights we have at work and very damaging to manufacturing jobs. ', ' But Mr Johnson hit back, and raged: Mr Corbyn and the Labour Party, in order to secure power, are going to a deal with Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP to form a Corbyn / Surgeon coalition and the price of that would be a second referendum on the union with Scotland. ', 'We had one in 2014, and we don’ t need another one.', 'Why put this great country through another referendum ? ', ' Mr Corbyn snapped : There won’ t be a coalition between Labour or anyone else.No deal has been done. ', ' 10.30 pm update: Sturgeon not impressed with Johnson and Corbyn - Not fit to be PM ', ' The SNP leader insists she wasn’ t impressed with either rival leader as they clashed in the first live television debate before the general election. ', ' Ms Sturgeon says she did not believe either man was fit to be Prime Minister on the strength of these performances. ', ' The clear takeaway for Scotland from this debate is that neither of these men should be able to determine Scotland 's future.', ' Jeremy Corbyn can 't decide if he is leave or remain and Boris Johnson is determined to take Scotland out of the EU against our will.', ' Only a vote for the SNP in this election can help Scotland escape from Brexit - and secure our right to choose a better future as an independent country. ', ' 10.20 pm update: Lib Dem leader vows to revoke Article 50 on first day as PM if elected ', 'Jo Swinson also rules out forming a coalition with either the Conservatives or Labour.', ' She says: Liberal Democrat votes are not going to put either Boris Johnson or Jeremy Corbyn into power because I believe our country deserves better than either of them. ', ' Both men are a product of their party. ', ' Even if they changed their leader I don 't think there' s any guarantee that they would be a more moderate figure. ', ' 10.15 pm update: Swinson attacks Johnson's and Corbyn's performance in debate ', ' The Liberal Democrat leader goes on the attack against her general election rivals. ', ' She says: People at home can be forgiven for thinking surely we deserve better than this.', ' We need something fresh and something different and a better choice - I 'm standing here as leader of the Liberal Democrats offering that better choice. ', ' 10 pm update: Rival leaders to be interviewed following live TV debate ', ' Following a break ofan hour, Jo Swinson, Nicola Sturgeon and Nigel Farage will now be interviewed. ', ' The rival party leaders were not part of the live television debate that involved Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn. ', ' 8.57 pm update: Johnson accuses Corbyn of being unfit to be Prime Minister', 'In his closing remarks, the Prime Minister goes on the attack against his rival for 10 Downing Street. ', 'He says: Mr Corbyn, you 've heard tonight, cannot answer the fundamental questions.', 'Is he for Remain or Leave and what price would he pay to secure Nicola Sturgeon 's support to enter Number 10?', 'If he can't answer those questions tonight, I don 't think he's fit to lead our country.', '8.55 pm update: Corbyn urges public to vote in a once - in -a - generation election ', 'In his closing remarks, Jeremy Corbyn says:  This is a once - in -a - generation election to end privatisation and give the National Health Service the funding it needs.To give people the final say and get Brexit sorted.', ' To tackle the climate emergency that threatens our futures.To invest good jobs in every region and nation of our country. ', 'I ask that you vote for hope and vote Labour on December 12. ', '8.54 pm update: Leaders asked which Christmas presents they would buy each other ', 'During one of the more relaxed moments in the fiery debate, the Prime Minister hopefuls are asked what presents they would buy each other.', 'Mr Corbyn says: I know Mr Johnson likes a good read, so what I would probably leave under the tree for him would be A Christmas Carol by Charles Dickens and he could then understand how nasty Scrooge was.', ' But Mr Johnson again turns the focus back to Brexit again, and replies: I would probably leave a copy - since you want a literary reference - a copy of my brilliant Brexit deal. ', 'He is then pressed by host Julie Etchingham to give a non - political answer, and replies: Mr Corbyn shares my love of plants and trees.I think maybe some damson jam, to which Mr Corbyn says: I love damson jam.', '8.53 pm update: Johnson and Corbyn asked which world leader they admire most ', ' Mr Johnson replies: I like the EU27, all of them, because they did me a fantastic deal.', 'But the Prime Minister is quickly shut down when he again tres to ask Mr Corbyn over his position on a second referendum. ', 'On the same question, the Labour leader says: I think the person I admire most in the world at the present time is the general secretary of the United Nations Antonio Guterres. ', 'He 's trying to bring the world together.', '8.51 pm update: Leaders asked if monarchty is fit for purpose', 'When asked if the monarchy is fit for purpose, the Labour leader says it needs a bit of improvement.', 'Mr Johnson says: The institution of the monarchy is beyond reproach.', '8.50pm update: Both leaders repeat commitment to investing in public services', 'Boris Johnson and Jeremy Corbyn pledged to increase Gpovrnment spending after the general election on December 12.', 'Mr Corbyn says: We will end austerity, I am absolutely clear about that because it is so brutal on the lives of so many people.', 'The Prime Minister says: I believe in spending, investing massively in our public services because we support ... a dynamic wealth-creating sector.', '8.48pm update: Johnson hits out at Labour’s crack-pot plan for a four-day week', 'The Labour Party has pledged to introduce a four-day week for workers as part of plans to give them more power.', 'But Mr Johnson raged: What could be more ruinous for the NHS than a crackpot plan for a four-day week, which would add massively to the burdens not just of the NHS but of every public service in the country?', '8.45pm update: NHS is one of the single most beautiful and brilliant things about Britain', 'The Prime Minister adds: We are determined to fund it not just now but for the long-term.', '8.44pm update: We’ve got to fund our NHS properly - Corbyn', 'Mr Corbyn tells a story about a friend of mine who died on Monday morning from secondary breast cancer.','The Labour leader says: The day before she had gone to hospital at the recommendation of her GP in order to get urgent treatment.', 'She waited eight hours, the nurses that were trying to help her were unable to get anyone to see her because they were under such strain and stress.', 'And so she recorded a video saying please, in my memory, make sure nobody else goes through this pain .', 'We've got to fund our NHS properly and fill the vacancies and make sure it 's there for all time.', '8.43pm update: Johnson and Corbyn SHAKE HANDS.', 'The two leaders stunned the audience by shaking hands after agreeing to work together to tackle nastiness in politics.', 'They are asked by host Julie Etchingham to make a gesture towards one another after what she described as a hostile political environment.', 'She says: Will you shake hands to make a pledge to improve politics?', 'Mr Johnson then walked over to Mr Corbyn, and they shook hands.', '8.42pm update: Corbyn challenged on anti-Semitism in Labour', 'He replies: I have taken action in my party where anyone that has committed any anti-Semitic acts, they are suspended or expelled from the party.', 'We are deadly serious about this.', 'We have to stand up against racism in any form of our society.', 'But Mr Johnson rages: Its a complete failure of leadership within the Labour Party. ', '8.40 pm update: Johnson laughed at by audience over truth', 'The Prime Minister draws laughter from the audience when he insists the truth does matter.', 'On Brexit, he again says: Mr Corbyn has not come clean over what he would do about whether he would support that deal or not.', '8.38 pm update: We have to bring people together - Corbyn.', 'Responding further to the question of trust in the leaders, Mr Corbyn says: We have to take decisions and be honest with people about how you can bring them together. ', 'My strategy on Brexit has been to recognise whether you voted to remain or leave - your issues are the same.', 'Bring people together.Don’ t divide them.', '8.36 pm update: Johnson accuses Labour of blocking Brexit', 'The Prime Minister says: Trust in politics and parliament has been corroded and the reason for that is parliament has refused to respect the views of the people. ', 'Jeremy Corbyn and the Labour Party are blocking Brexit.', 'But the Labour leader hits back: Trust un politics and parliament has been corroded and the reason for that is parliament has refused to respect the views of the people.', '8.33pm update: Johnson and Corbyn attacked for leadership', 'An audience member asks how the country can trust the leaders when under their leadership, the debate has become  toxic .', 'He adds: How can this nation trust you to look after our interests ? ', '8.26pm update: Boris hits back at Corbyn over breakup of the union', 'The Prime Minister says:  Mr Corbyn and the Labour Party, in order to secure power, are going to a deal with Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP to form a Corbyn / Surgeon coalition and the price of that would be a second referendum on the union with Scotland. ', 'We had one in 2014, and we don’t need another one.', ' Why put this great country through another referendum ?', 'Mr Corbyn hits back: There won’ t be a coalition between Labour or anyone else. No deal has been done.', '8.24pm update: Leaders are asked: Is the union worth sacrificing for Brexit?', 'Mr Cobyn replies:  I hope the union won’ t be broken up in this way but the deal the Prime Minister has put to parliament is about creating a border between the Republic and Northern Ireland. ', 'Clearly there are issues all around the deal he has proposed.', 'This deal is damaging to the country, damaging to the rights we have at work and very damaging to manufacturing jobs.', '8.17pm update: Corbyn and Johnson clash over NHS in trade agreement', 'Mr Corbyn rages at Mr Johnson, accusing him of selling the NHS out to the United States.', 'But the Prime Minister hits back:  This is an absolute invention, completely untrue and there are no circumstance in which this Government will put the NHS on the table in any trade negotiation ', 'This NHS will never be for sale.', 'Mr Corbyn is tying to conceal the void at the heart of his Brexit policy and refusing to answer the question on which side he will take.', '8.11pm update: Johnson continues to ask Corbyn his position in referendum', 'The Prime Minister continues to reiterate we don’t know which side Mr Corbyn would campaign in another Brexit referendum', 'The Labour leader replies: We will negotiate an agreement and will put that alongside remain in a referendum.', 'I will carry out the result of that referendum.', 'Mr Johnson turns to Mr Corbyn and says directly : Are you going to campaign for leave or remain ?', 'But the Labour again refuses to answer directly, and replies : We want to bring people together, therefore there will be a referendum in which that decision will be made by the British people. and our Government will abide by that decision.', '8.08 pm update : PM 's plan to get Brexit done by January 31 nonsence ', 'Mr Corbyn insists Labour will negotiate a credible leave option with the EU and within six months put that to a referendum of the British people, offering them a leave and remain option. ', ' He rages: The idea the Prime Minister 's deal can be dealt with and finished with by the end of January is such nonsense.', '8.05pm update: Leaders facing questions from studio audience', 'The first audience member to ask a question accused the pair of broken promises over delivering Brexit and asks for reassurance that we won't be talking about this forever. ', ' Mr Johnson insists the UK will come out on January 31 because he has a deal ready to go.', 'He says: There is a sharp distinction to what we are proposing - getting Brexit done, unleashing the potential of this country.', 'Jeremy Corbyn cannot tell us what side he would campaign on in a referendum.', '8 pm update: Corbyn is first to speak as he makes his openning statement ', 'He says the election gives you a choice about your future.', 'Mr Corbyn insists Labour is offering real change and real hope.', 'He says a Tory Government has failed on economy, climate crisis, NHS and Brexit.', 'The Labour leader adds: We will get Brexit sorted by giving you the final say.', '7.35 pm update: Corbyn arrives for live TV debate with Johnson ', 'The Labour Party leader has arrived for the live television debate with the Prime Minister. ', ' Mr Corbyn posed for pictures with supporters and waved to the crowd as he entered the MediaCity building in Salford. ', '7.20 pm update: Tories surge into huge 18 - point lead at‘ expense’ of Brexit Party - poll ', 'The Conservative Party has surged into a huge 18 - point lead over Labour in a new poll ahead of the general election on December 12 at the expense of plummeting support for the Brexit Party. ', ' The opinion poll from Kantar of 1,176 people online between November 14 - 18 revealed support for the Tories has ballooned over recent days.', 'This has increased eight percent to 45 percent from the last Kantar poll published six days ago.The Labour Party remains unchanged on 27 percent but is now a massive 18 - points behind the ruling party just three weeks before the general election.'

commentThread.commentText: Etchingham should not have made sarcastic remarks about coins and ditches - it shows prejudice against Boris

"Credible leave option" - Why doesn't he say "Leave option"? The fact he has to prefix it with credible means it will be a long way from actually being a clean break from the EU. It 's like saying to someone "yes I will give you a job, on a fair salary". A fair salary being only fair in the eyes of the person judging how much to pay you. If they said instead "I will give you a job and it will pay you an impressive £60,000 a year" then there would be no need to prefix it with "fair".  So Corbyn 's leave option would be a "fair salary" option, credible only in the eyes of someone who wants to remain.

commentThread.commentText: QT a remain promotion show, high time the Biased PC Broadcasting Curse, was made to pay its way in the world. Abolish the extortionist licence fee.

In contrast to 'Ladies Night' on ITV Second Debate - Nigel made most sens!!.. He was so right when he said that greatest problem of lately in our Political/Parliamentary System is Lack of 'Losers Consent' - which leads to Politicians and public! not being able to ACCEPT Voters' Majority Decisions and instead of Implementing Results - they are being ignored, contested, distressed and skewed in every which way - for political gains and popularity. Basically FAR from Democracy we still want to Believe in and Respect. Is there any Point to more of these TV Debates?? I don't know. Wish GE was this week!! ------------

Watched both Debates. First one conducted by Julie Etchingham was rather 'flat' and predictable..Little bit like watching QT, or PM's Wednesday's Debates in Parliament. Boris very much himself - enthusiastic, passionate, repetitive about Brexit itself, but understandably so. After all Brexit paralysis resulted in this particular GE. Corbyn very much himself too - usual moaning, evasive, trying to put some 'evidence' out of the sleeve to stunt Boris with alleged Tory 'US Deals' concerning Medical Supplies to our NHS..That didn't work either Corbyn's way. All in all - Sam e old, sa me old. ------------- I was pretty much impressed thou by a Format of Second Debate conducted by Nina Hossain!And here I have to say - she has shown a different Class and interviewing skills we became so accustom to on practically all News Channels and..grown more and more appalled by behaviour of their regular Presenters!One, by one.. Nina allowed each Guest to answer her Qs without interruption, aggression, pulling faces, annoyance, intimidation, but Most of All - she was refreshingly UN - BIASED!!And indeed each Political Leader had a chance to put their views in very compelling way - without shouting, screeching, foaming at mouth - otherwise in proper and civilized manner!!Bravo that Lady!!-- -- -- -- -- --Never thought I could actually listen to Swinson, Sturgeon and Berry in full that 's a first!: The biggest Impediment of All three women is sadly their stance on Democracy..what Democracy!??

There was only one winner tonight. Well done Mr Putin.
